definition:
If $\Phi$ is a class of $n$-ary relations with $\vec{x}$ as the only
free variables, an $n+1$-ary formula $\psi$ is *universal* for $\Phi$ if
for any $\phi\in\Phi$ there is some $e$ such that
$\psi(e,\vec{x})\leftrightarrow\phi(\vec{x})$. In other words, $\psi$
can simulate any element of $\Phi$.

Similarly, if $\Phi$ is a class of function of $\vec{x}$, a formula
$\psi$ is universal for $\Phi$ if for any $\phi\in\Phi$ there is some
$e$ such that $\psi(e,\vec{x})=\phi(\vec{x})$.
